cards.title: üß† Logical Fallacies
cards.subtitle: Master Critical Thinking
cards.description: Learn to identify common errors in reasoning that can mislead arguments and debates. Swipe through to discover fallacies that appear everywhere from social media to political discourse.
cards.example: Understanding these patterns will help you think more clearly, argue more effectively, and avoid being manipulated by flawed reasoning.
cards.tip: Take your time with each one. Real mastery comes from recognizing these fallacies in everyday conversations!

cards.title: üë§ Ad Hominem
cards.subtitle: Attacking the Person
cards.description: Attacking the person making an argument rather than addressing the argument itself.
cards.example: You can't trust John's opinion on climate change because he's not a scientist.
cards.tip: Focus on the argument's merit, not who's making it.

cards.title: üé™ Straw Man
cards.subtitle: Misrepresenting the Argument
cards.description: Misrepresenting someone's argument to make it easier to attack.
cards.example: Person A: We should have some gun control. Person B: So you want to take away all guns?
cards.tip: Always address the actual argument being made.

cards.title: ‚ö´‚ö™ False Dichotomy
cards.subtitle: Black-and-White Thinking
cards.description: Presenting only two options when more exist.
cards.example: You're either with us or against us.
cards.tip: Look for middle ground and additional alternatives.

cards.title: üëî Appeal to Authority
cards.subtitle: Improper Authority
cards.description: Using an authority figure's opinion as evidence when they lack relevant expertise.
cards.example: This famous actor says this diet works, so it must be healthy.
cards.tip: Check if the authority is actually an expert in the relevant field.

cards.title: üéø Slippery Slope
cards.subtitle: Chain Reaction Fallacy
cards.description: Arguing that one step will inevitably lead to extreme consequences without evidence.
cards.example: If we allow students to redo assignments, soon grades will be meaningless.
cards.tip: Each step in a chain needs its own justification.

cards.title: üèÉ Hasty Generalization
cards.subtitle: Jumping to Conclusions
cards.description: Drawing a broad conclusion from limited evidence.
cards.example: I met two rude people from that city, so everyone there must be rude.
cards.tip: Ensure your sample size is large and representative.

cards.title: üîÑ Circular Reasoning
cards.subtitle: Begging the Question
cards.description: Using the conclusion as a premise in your argument.
cards.example: The Bible is true because it says so in the Bible.
cards.tip: Your premises must be independent of your conclusion.

cards.title: üêü Red Herring
cards.subtitle: Distracting from the Issue
cards.description: Introducing irrelevant information to distract from the actual issue.
cards.example: Why worry about the environment when there are people starving?
cards.tip: Stay focused on the topic being discussed.

cards.title: üöê Bandwagon
cards.subtitle: Appeal to Popularity
cards.description: Arguing something is true because many people believe it.
cards.example: Everyone's buying this product, so it must be good.

cards.title: ‚è∞ Post Hoc
cards.subtitle: False Cause
cards.description: Assuming that because B follows A, A must have caused B.
cards.example: I wore my lucky socks and we won the game, so my socks caused our victory.

cards.title: üò¢ Appeal to Emotion
cards.subtitle: Playing on Feelings
cards.description: Manipulating emotions instead of using valid reasoning to persuade.
cards.example: If you don't support this law, you must hate children.
cards.tip: Strong emotions don't make an argument logically sound.

cards.title: ü™û Tu Quoque
cards.subtitle: You Too Fallacy
cards.description: Dismissing criticism by pointing out the critic's hypocrisy.
cards.example: You say I shouldn't smoke, but you used to smoke too!
cards.tip: Hypocrisy doesn't make the criticism wrong.

cards.title: üåø Appeal to Nature
cards.subtitle: Natural Equals Good
cards.description: Arguing that something is good because it's natural.
cards.example: This medicine is better because it's all-natural and organic.
cards.tip: Arsenic is natural. Natural doesn't mean safe.

cards.title: üéØ Texas Sharpshooter
cards.subtitle: Cherry-Picking Data
cards.description: Selecting data that supports your conclusion while ignoring data that doesn't.
cards.example: Look at all these warm days - global warming is happening!
cards.tip: Look at all the data, not just what supports your view.

cards.title: üè¥ No True Scotsman
cards.subtitle: Moving the Goalposts
cards.description: Changing the definition to exclude counterexamples.
cards.example: No true Christian would do that. Well, he's not a TRUE Christian then.
cards.tip: Definitions shouldn't change to preserve your argument.

cards.title: ü™§ Loaded Question
cards.subtitle: Trap Questions
cards.description: Asking a question that contains an unproven assumption.
cards.example: Have you stopped cheating on tests?
cards.tip: Challenge the assumptions built into questions.

cards.title: ‚öñÔ∏è Middle Ground
cards.subtitle: False Compromise
cards.description: Assuming the truth lies in the middle of two extreme positions.
cards.example: Some say vaccines are safe, others deadly. Truth is in between.
cards.tip: Sometimes one side is simply right and the other wrong.

cards.title: üìã Burden of Proof
cards.subtitle: Prove Me Wrong
cards.description: Claiming something is true until proven false.
cards.example: Bigfoot exists. Prove to me that he doesn't!
cards.tip: The person making a claim has the burden to prove it.

cards.title: üèõÔ∏è Appeal to Tradition
cards.subtitle: We've Always Done It
cards.description: Arguing something is correct because it's been done historically.
cards.example: We've always done it this way, so we should continue.
cards.tip: Tradition doesn't justify an action's correctness.

cards.title: üß¨ Genetic Fallacy
cards.subtitle: Judging by Origin
cards.description: Judging something based on where it comes from.
cards.example: That theory came from a discredited scientist, so it's wrong.
cards.tip: Evaluate ideas on their own merit, not their source.

cards.title: üß© Composition
cards.subtitle: Parts to Whole
cards.description: Assuming what's true for the parts must be true for the whole.
cards.example: Each player is excellent, so the team must be excellent.
cards.tip: A collection can have different properties than its parts.

cards.title: ‚úÇÔ∏è Division
cards.subtitle: Whole to Parts
cards.description: Assuming what's true for the whole must be true for the parts.
cards.example: This company is profitable, so every department is profitable.
cards.tip: Individual parts may differ from the collective whole.

cards.title: üîÄ Equivocation
cards.subtitle: Shifting Meanings
cards.description: Using the same word with different meanings in an argument.
cards.example: A feather is light. Light is opposite of dark. Feather is opposite of dark.

cards.title: üìñ Anecdotal Evidence
cards.subtitle: My Experience Proves It
cards.description: Using personal experience as the sole evidence.
cards.example: My grandfather smoked and lived to 95, so smoking isn't bad.
cards.tip: Individual cases don't disprove statistical trends.

cards.title: ‚ùì Appeal to Ignorance
cards.subtitle: Absence of Evidence
cards.description: Claiming something is true because it hasn't been proven false.
cards.example: No one has proven aliens don't exist, so they must be real.
cards.tip: Lack of evidence isn't evidence itself.

cards.title: üé≠ Special Pleading
cards.subtitle: Rules for Thee, Not for Me
cards.description: Applying rules to others but claiming you're exempt.
cards.example: Everyone should follow speed limits, but I'm a good driver.

cards.title: üí∏ Sunk Cost
cards.subtitle: Can't Waste the Investment
cards.description: Continuing because you've already invested.
cards.example: I've already spent $500 fixing this car, so I have to keep fixing it.
cards.tip: Past investments shouldn't dictate future decisions.

cards.title: üé≤ Gambler's Fallacy
cards.subtitle: Due for a Win
cards.description: Believing past random events affect future independent events.
cards.example: The coin landed heads five times, so tails is due next.

cards.title: üçéüçä False Analogy
cards.subtitle: Apples to Oranges
cards.description: Comparing two things that aren't sufficiently similar.
cards.example: Employees are like nails. Nails must be hit to work, so must employees.
cards.tip: Analogies only work when similarities are relevant.

cards.title: ü•Ö Moving the Goalposts
cards.subtitle: Never Satisfied
cards.description: Changing requirements when they've been met.
cards.example: Show evidence. That's not enough. I meant different evidence.

cards.title: ü§° Appeal to Ridicule
cards.subtitle: Mocking the Argument
cards.description: Presenting an opponent's argument as absurd.
cards.example: Oh sure, and the moon is made of cheese!

cards.title: üåä Overwhelming Exception
cards.subtitle: Exception Swallows Rule
cards.description: Citing an exception as if it disproves the rule.
cards.example: Exercise is healthy? My friend got injured exercising!

cards.title: ‚ö° Nirvana Fallacy
cards.subtitle: Perfect or Nothing
cards.description: Rejecting a solution because it's not perfect.
cards.example: This safety measure won't prevent ALL accidents.
cards.tip: Better is still better, even if not perfect.

cards.title: üé£ Argument from Fallacy
cards.subtitle: Fallacy Fallacy
cards.description: If an argument has a fallacy, the conclusion must be false.
cards.example: Your argument used a fallacy, so exercise isn't beneficial.
cards.tip: A bad argument doesn't make the conclusion wrong.

cards.title: üë• Appeal to Pity
cards.subtitle: Sympathy Over Logic
cards.description: Winning support through sympathy rather than reasoning.
cards.example: I've been having a hard time, so give me an A.

cards.title: üí™ Appeal to Force
cards.subtitle: Might Makes Right
cards.description: Using threats instead of reasoning.
cards.example: Believe what I say or you'll lose your job.
cards.tip: Threats don't make an argument valid.

cards.title: üåü Appeal to Novelty
cards.subtitle: New Must Be Better
cards.description: Assuming something is better because it's newer.
cards.example: This new app must be better just because it's newer.

cards.title: üéñÔ∏è Appeal to Accomplishment
cards.subtitle: Success in One, Expert in All
cards.description: Expertise in one field grants expertise in all.
cards.example: She's a great athlete, so her political opinions are valid.

cards.title: üí∞ Appeal to Wealth
cards.subtitle: Rich Means Right
cards.description: Someone is correct because they are wealthy.
cards.example: He's a billionaire, so he's right about economics.

cards.title: üßπ Reductio ad Absurdum
cards.subtitle: Misused Reduction to Absurdity
cards.description: Taking an argument to extremes improperly.
cards.example: If we allow gay marriage, people will marry their pets!
cards.tip: Valid when logical, invalid when exaggerating.

cards.title: üì∫ Proof by Assertion
cards.subtitle: Repeat Until True
cards.description: Repeating a statement as if repetition makes it true.
cards.example: This is the best. Simply the best. Everyone knows it's the best.

cards.title: üé™ False Equivalence
cards.subtitle: Both Sides Are Equal
cards.description: Treating unequal things as equal.
cards.example: A jaywalker and murderer are both criminals, so they're the same.
cards.tip: Not all things in a category are equally significant.

cards.title: üé® Fallacy of Composition
cards.subtitle: Good for One, Good for All
cards.description: What benefits one will benefit the group.
cards.example: If one person stands at a concert, everyone should stand.

cards.title: üï∞Ô∏è Chronological Snobbery
cards.subtitle: Old Means Wrong
cards.description: Dismissing ideas because they're old.
cards.example: That book is 100 years old, so it can't be relevant.

cards.title: üéØ Cherry Picking
cards.subtitle: Selective Evidence
cards.description: Selecting only favorable evidence.
cards.example: Look at these five studies that support my view.

cards.title: ü§ù Guilt by Association
cards.subtitle: Bad Company, Bad Ideas
cards.description: Discrediting by association with undesirable groups.
cards.example: Hitler was a vegetarian, so vegetarianism is bad.

cards.title: üé¨ Historian's Fallacy
cards.subtitle: They Should Have Known
cards.description: Assuming past people had current information.
cards.example: How could they not know smoking was bad in the 1950s?

cards.title: üîÆ Appeal to Mystery
cards.subtitle: Patterns in Randomness
cards.description: Cherry-picking clusters in random data.
cards.example: Three people from this town got sick - must be the water!

cards.title: üé≠ Appeal to Fear
cards.subtitle: Scare Tactics
cards.description: Using fear to manipulate acceptance.
cards.example: If you don't vote for this, our way of life will be destroyed!

cards.title: üèÅ Proof by Example
cards.subtitle: One Example Proves All
cards.description: Using one example as proof of a universal claim.
cards.example: My uncle smoked and lived to 100, so smoking isn't harmful.
cards.tip: One example doesn't establish a pattern.

cards.title: üé∞ Appeal to Probability
cards.subtitle: If It Can, It Will
cards.description: Assuming possibility equals inevitability.
cards.example: Someone will misuse this, so ban it now.

cards.title: üîç Spotlight Fallacy
cards.subtitle: Media Equals Reality
cards.description: Media coverage represents full reality.
cards.example: News shows crime, so crime is rising.

cards.title: üéì Argument from Authority
cards.subtitle: Expert Says, Must Be True
cards.description: Accepting claims just because an expert said it.
cards.example: Nobel winner said it, must be true.

cards.title: üåà Continuum Fallacy
cards.subtitle: No Clear Line, No Difference
cards.description: Rejecting distinction due to unclear boundary.
cards.example: No exact moment day becomes night, so no difference.

cards.title: üé™ Kettle Logic
cards.subtitle: Contradictory Arguments
cards.description: Using contradictory arguments together.
cards.example: Never borrowed it. Was broken. Returned perfect.

cards.title: üîî Affirming the Consequent
cards.subtitle: Backward Logic
cards.description: If A causes B, then B proves A.
cards.example: Rain makes grass wet. Grass wet, so it rained.

cards.title: ‚ùå Denying the Antecedent
cards.subtitle: Wrong Direction
cards.description: If A causes B, not-A means not-B.
cards.example: Study to pass. Didn't study, won't pass.
cards.tip: Absence of one cause doesn't eliminate all.

cards.title: üéØ Base Rate Fallacy
cards.subtitle: Ignoring Background Rate
cards.description: Ignoring overall probability.
cards.example: 99% accurate test, you're positive, so you have it.

cards.title: üé≤ Conjunction Fallacy
cards.subtitle: More Detail, More Likely
cards.description: Specific seems more likely than general.
cards.example: Linda is more likely feminist bank teller than bank teller.

cards.title: üß† Mind Projection
cards.subtitle: My Thoughts Are Reality
cards.description: Mental states reflect objective reality.
cards.example: This music is objectively bad because I dislike it.

cards.title: üé≠ Motte-and-Bailey
cards.subtitle: Defend Weak, Assert Strong
cards.description: Switching between controversial and defensible positions.
cards.example: Abolish prisons. I meant reform prisons.
cards.tip: Don't let retreat to weaker claims.

cards.title: üåÄ Kafkatrapping
cards.subtitle: Denial Proves Guilt
cards.description: Denial itself is proof of guilt.
cards.example: Not racist? That's what racists say!

cards.title: üí≠ Thought-Terminating Clich√©
cards.subtitle: Conversation Ender
cards.description: Catchy phrases shut down thinking.
cards.example: It is what it is. Boys will be boys.

cards.title: üé™ Two Wrongs Make Right
cards.subtitle: Their Wrong Justifies Mine
cards.description: Others' wrongs justify yours.
cards.example: Sure I cheated, everyone does!

cards.title: ‚öñÔ∏è False Balance
cards.subtitle: Equal Time for Unequal
cards.description: Giving equal weight to unequal positions.
cards.example: 99% of scientists vs one skeptic - both sides!

cards.title: üîä Argument from Loudness
cards.subtitle: Yelling Means Winning
cards.description: Speaking louder makes argument valid.
cards.example: Shouting over someone in debate.

cards.title: üéØ Ecological Fallacy
cards.subtitle: Group Stats to Individuals
cards.description: Group truth applies to individuals.
cards.example: High income neighborhood, so everyone is wealthy.

cards.title: üé® McNamara Fallacy
cards.subtitle: Only Measurable Matters
cards.description: Decisions based only on metrics.
cards.example: Student learning is only test scores.

cards.title: üé™ Psychologist's Fallacy
cards.subtitle: Observer Bias as Fact
cards.description: Projecting your perspective into subjects.
cards.example: Baby smiled, so it recognizes me.

cards.title: üé≠ Package Deal
cards.subtitle: All or Nothing Bundle
cards.description: Positions must always go together.
cards.example: Support gun rights? Must oppose abortion.

cards.title: üîÑ Circular Cause
cards.subtitle: Chicken and Egg
cards.description: A causes B and B causes A.
cards.example: Depressed because unemployed, unemployed because depressed.

cards.title: üíé Appeal to Consequences
cards.subtitle: Truth Based on Outcomes
cards.description: True or false based on liking consequences.
cards.example: Can't be no afterlife, too depressing.

cards.title: üéØ Sharpshooter's Fallacy
cards.subtitle: Paint Target After
cards.description: Adjusting hypothesis after seeing data.
cards.example: Predicted something big, celebrity divorced!

cards.title: üåü Wishful Thinking
cards.subtitle: Belief Shapes Reality
cards.description: True because you want it true.
cards.example: Don't need to study, will pass because I need to.

cards.title: üé≠ Appeal to Flattery
cards.subtitle: Compliments Replace Logic
cards.description: Using praise to get acceptance.
cards.example: Someone as smart as you agrees...

cards.title: ‚ö° Lightning Fallacy
cards.subtitle: Sudden Insight Must Be True
cards.description: Sudden realization must be true.
cards.example: Suddenly became clear - this is the answer!

cards.title: üé™ Availability Heuristic
cards.subtitle: Easy Recall Means Common
cards.description: Judging likelihood by ease of recall.
cards.example: Plane crashes are so common!

cards.title: üéØ Anchoring Bias
cards.subtitle: First Number Sticks
cards.description: Over-relying on first information.
cards.example: Listed at $30K, so $25K is great!
cards.tip: Don't let initial info anchor you.

cards.title: üé™ Confirmation Bias
cards.subtitle: See What You Want
cards.description: Seeking info confirming beliefs.
cards.example: Horoscope was right today!

cards.title: üîç Hindsight Bias
cards.subtitle: I Knew It All Along
cards.description: Past events seemed more predictable.
cards.example: I knew that team would win!

cards.title: üë§ Fundamental Attribution Error
cards.subtitle: Character Over Circumstance
cards.description: Overemphasizing personality over situation.
cards.example: He cut me off - terrible person!

cards.title: üé≠ Actor-Observer Bias
cards.subtitle: Different Rules for Me
cards.description: Your actions situational, others' character.
cards.example: I was late because traffic, you because irresponsible.

cards.title: üåü Halo Effect
cards.subtitle: One Good, All Good
cards.description: One positive quality influences all judgment.
cards.example: She's attractive, so also smart and kind.

cards.title: üòà Horn Effect
cards.subtitle: One Bad, All Bad
cards.description: One negative quality influences all.
cards.example: He made a mistake, so incompetent at everything.

cards.title: üéØ Dunning-Kruger Effect
cards.subtitle: Ignorance Breeds Confidence
cards.description: Overestimating knowledge when knowing little.
cards.example: Watched YouTube video, know more than doctors.
cards.tip: More you learn, more you don't know.

cards.title: üé™ Impostor Syndrome
cards.subtitle: Expertise Breeds Doubt
cards.description: Doubting abilities despite competence.
cards.example: Only got PhD because lucky, not capable.

cards.title: üí≠ Clustering Illusion
cards.subtitle: Patterns in Randomness
cards.description: Finding patterns where none exist.
cards.example: Keep seeing 11:11, must mean something!

cards.title: üé≤ Hot Hand Fallacy
cards.subtitle: Streaks Mean Momentum
cards.description: Success streaks will continue.
cards.example: Won three coin flips, on a hot streak!

cards.title: üéØ Survivorship Bias
cards.subtitle: Success Story Selection
cards.description: Focusing on successes, ignoring failures.
cards.example: Dropouts like Gates became billionaires!

cards.title: üìä Regression to Mean
cards.subtitle: Extreme Results Normalize
cards.description: Not accounting for return to average.
cards.example: Back pain went away after healer!

cards.title: üé™ Self-Serving Bias
cards.subtitle: Credit Success, Blame Circumstances
cards.description: Successes yours, failures external.
cards.example: Passed because smart, failed because unfair test.

cards.title: üë• Ingroup Bias
cards.subtitle: My Group Better
cards.description: Favoring your own group.
cards.example: Lost due to luck, they won by cheating.

cards.title: üåç Outgroup Homogeneity
cards.subtitle: They're All Same
cards.description: Perceiving outgroups as more similar.
cards.example: All millennials are entitled.

cards.title: üéØ Projection Bias
cards.subtitle: Everyone Thinks Like Me
cards.description: Assuming others share your views.
cards.example: I love spicy food, great gift for anyone!

cards.title: üîÆ Planning Fallacy
cards.subtitle: Underestimating Time
cards.description: Underestimating time and costs.
cards.example: This will take 2 weeks. Takes 2 months.

cards.title: ‚è∞ Present Bias
cards.subtitle: Now Over Later
cards.description: Overvaluing immediate rewards.
cards.example: Start diet tomorrow, eat cake today.

cards.title: üé™ Hyperbolic Discounting
cards.subtitle: Near Beats Distant
cards.description: Preferring smaller immediate over larger delayed.
cards.example: $50 now better than $100 in a year.

cards.title: üéØ Framing Effect
cards.subtitle: Presentation Changes Perception
cards.description: Same info, different conclusions by framing.
cards.example: 90% survival sounds better than 10% death.

cards.title: üé≠ Distinction Bias
cards.subtitle: Comparison Exaggerates
cards.description: Overvaluing differences when comparing.
cards.example: These headphones sound way better in store!

cards.title: üí≠ Information Bias
cards.subtitle: More Info Better
cards.description: Seeking info that won't affect decision.
cards.example: Researching hours when differences trivial.

cards.title: üéØ Ostrich Effect
cards.subtitle: Avoiding Negative Info
cards.description: Ignoring dangerous information.
cards.example: Not checking bank balance when low.

cards.title: üåü Optimism Bias
cards.subtitle: Bad Things to Others
cards.description: Less likely to experience negatives.
cards.example: Don't need insurance, won't happen to me.

cards.title: üò∞ Pessimism Bias
cards.subtitle: Overestimating Negatives
cards.description: Expecting worst more likely.
cards.example: Speak up, definitely get fired.

cards.title: üé™ Normalcy Bias
cards.subtitle: Everything Stays Same
cards.description: Underestimating disaster likelihood.
cards.example: Fire alarm is probably just drill.

cards.title: ‚ö° Recency Bias
cards.subtitle: Recent More Important
cards.description: More weight to recent events.
cards.example: Market crashed yesterday, bad time to invest.

cards.title: üéØ Peak-End Rule
cards.subtitle: Peaks and Ends Define Memory
cards.description: Judging by peak and end.
cards.example: Vacation was amazing! Last day was great.

cards.title: üíé Endowment Effect
cards.subtitle: My Stuff More Valuable
cards.description: Overvaluing because you own it.
cards.example: Won't sell car for $10K, wouldn't pay $10K either.

cards.title: üé≠ IKEA Effect
cards.subtitle: I Made It, Better
cards.description: Overvaluing what you created.
cards.example: Wobbly table I built worth more than store-bought!

cards.title: üåü Zero-Risk Bias
cards.subtitle: Eliminate One Risk
cards.description: Preferring one risk to zero over reducing multiple.
cards.example: Make X 100% safe instead of reducing all risks.

cards.title: üé™ Denomination Effect
cards.subtitle: Big Bills More Valuable
cards.description: Less likely to spend larger bills.
cards.example: Won't break $100, easily spend five $20s.

cards.title: üí≠ Mental Accounting
cards.subtitle: Money in Mental Buckets
cards.description: Treating money differently by category.
cards.example: Birthday money can splurge, salary be careful.

cards.title: üéØ Decoy Effect
cards.subtitle: Third Option Changes Preference
cards.description: Third inferior option changes preference.
cards.example: Small $3, Large $7, Medium $6.50 makes large good.

cards.title: üåà Rainbow Washing
cards.subtitle: Superficial Cause Support
cards.description: Appearing to support causes for profit.
cards.example: Support pride month, logo change June only.

cards.title: üé™ Greenwashing
cards.subtitle: False Environmental Claims
cards.description: Misleading environmental claims.
cards.example: Eco-friendly plastic! Still pollutes.

cards.title: üé≠ Virtue Signaling
cards.subtitle: Values Without Action
cards.description: Expressing opinions for moral superiority.
cards.example: Posting about causes, never helping.

cards.title: üí≠ Whataboutism
cards.subtitle: Deflecting with Other Issues
cards.description: Responding to criticism with different issue.
cards.example: Why criticize us? What about what they did?

cards.title: üéØ Golden Hammer
cards.subtitle: One Solution for All
cards.description: Over-relying on familiar tool.
cards.example: Know Excel, use it for everything!

cards.title: üé™ Not Invented Here
cards.subtitle: Rejecting External Ideas
cards.description: Avoiding solutions from outside.
cards.example: Can't use their solution, build our own.

cards.title: ‚ö° Premature Optimization
cards.subtitle: Perfecting Before Knowing
cards.description: Optimizing before understanding needs.
cards.example: Weeks optimizing code that runs once daily.

cards.title: üé≠ Bikeshedding
cards.subtitle: Focusing on Trivial
cards.description: Disproportionate time on minor decisions.
cards.example: Hours debating paint color, quick million-dollar approvals.

cards.title: üåü Analysis Paralysis
cards.subtitle: Overthinking Prevents Deciding
cards.description: Unable to decide due to overanalyzing.
cards.example: Researching laptops for months, never buying.

cards.title: üíé Feature Creep
cards.subtitle: Adding Unnecessary Complexity
cards.description: Continuously adding features.
cards.example: Just one more feature... repeat 100 times.

cards.title: üéØ Scope Creep
cards.subtitle: Expanding Beyond Plan
cards.description: Requirements expanding without evaluation.
cards.example: While we're at it, let's also add...

cards.title: üé™ Perfectionism Paralysis
cards.subtitle: Nothing Good Enough
cards.description: Never completing because not perfect.
cards.example: Rewriting first chapter 50 times.

cards.title: ‚ö° Busy Work Fallacy
cards.subtitle: Activity Equals Productivity
cards.description: Confusing busy with productive.
cards.example: Sent 100 emails, accomplished nothing important.

cards.title: üé≠ Mere Exposure Effect
cards.subtitle: Familiarity Breeds Preference
cards.description: Preferring because familiar.
cards.example: Like song after hearing 20 times.

cards.title: üåü Authority Bias
cards.subtitle: Authority Must Be Right
cards.description: Trusting authority even when wrong.
cards.example: CEO said it, must be true.

cards.title: üéØ Bystander Effect
cards.subtitle: Someone Else Will Handle
cards.description: Not acting because others present.
cards.example: Someone else will help that person.

cards.title: üí≠ Just-World Hypothesis
cards.subtitle: Good to Good People
cards.description: World is fair, people get what deserve.
cards.example: They're poor, must be lazy.

cards.title: üé™ Barnum Effect
cards.subtitle: Vague Feels Personal
cards.description: Vague statements feel specifically about you.
cards.example: You need others to like you.

cards.title: üåà Choice-Supportive Bias
cards.subtitle: Retroactively Justifying
cards.description: Remembering choices as better.
cards.example: Glad I chose this car.

cards.title: ‚ö° Reactance
cards.subtitle: Resist Being Told
cards.description: Opposite of suggested because freedom threatened.
cards.example: Don't tell me what to do!

cards.title: üé≠ Illusory Superiority
cards.subtitle: I'm Better Than Average
cards.description: Overestimating positive qualities.
cards.example: I'm above-average driver.

cards.title: üíé Hard-Easy Effect
cards.subtitle: Confidence Inversely Related
cards.description: Overconfident on hard, underconfident on easy.
cards.example: This is impossible! vs No problem!

cards.title: üéØ Egocentric Bias
cards.subtitle: My Contribution Larger
cards.description: Overestimating own contributions.
cards.example: I did 80% of group project!
cards.tip: Others contributed more than you remember.

cards.title: üåü False Consensus
cards.subtitle: Everyone Agrees
cards.description: Overestimating agreement with beliefs.
cards.example: Everyone thinks this way.

cards.title: ‚ö° Curse of Knowledge
cards.subtitle: Can't Remember Not Knowing
cards.description: Difficulty imagining not knowing what you know.
cards.example: This is so obvious!

cards.title: üé™ Spotlight Effect
cards.subtitle: Everyone Watching
cards.description: Overestimating how much others notice.
cards.example: Everyone will notice this stain!

cards.title: üí≠ Illusion of Transparency
cards.subtitle: Thoughts Are Obvious
cards.description: Overestimating how well others understand you.
cards.example: They should know I'm upset!

cards.title: üé≠ Illusion of Control
cards.subtitle: Can Influence Random
cards.description: Overestimating influence over uncontrollable.
cards.example: Need lucky jersey for team to win!

cards.title: üåà Moral Luck
cards.subtitle: Judging by Outcomes
cards.description: Judging by outcomes rather than intent.
cards.example: Drove drunk but didn't hit anyone, not that bad.

cards.title: üéØ Outcome Bias
cards.subtitle: Results Determine Quality
cards.description: Judging decision by outcome.
cards.example: Terrible choice! Was good bet that lost.
cards.tip: Good decisions can have bad outcomes.

cards.title: ‚ö° Impact Bias
cards.subtitle: Overestimating Duration
cards.description: Overestimating emotional duration.
cards.example: Don't get job, devastated forever!

cards.title: üíé Restraint Bias
cards.subtitle: Overconfident Self-Control
cards.description: Overestimating ability to resist.
cards.example: Keep cookies, have willpower! Eats all.

cards.title: üé™ Time-Saving Bias
cards.subtitle: Overestimating Time Saved
cards.description: Overestimating time saved by speed.
cards.example: Speeding to save 2 minutes on 10 minute drive.

cards.title: üåü Effort Justification
cards.subtitle: Hard Work Makes Valuable
cards.description: Valuing outcomes more when effort required.
cards.example: Meal tastes better, spent 5 hours making it.

cards.title: üéØ Ben Franklin Effect
cards.subtitle: Favors Create Liking
cards.description: Liking someone more after doing favor.
cards.example: Helped them, so worth helping, like them now.

cards.title: üé≠ Reactance Theory
cards.subtitle: Forbidden Fruit Sweeter
cards.description: Wanting more when restricted.
cards.example: Don't think about pink elephants.

cards.title: üí≠ Zeigarnik Effect
cards.subtitle: Unfinished Tasks Haunt
cards.description: Remembering incomplete better than completed.
cards.example: Can't stop thinking about unfinished project.

cards.title: üéØ Blind Spot Bias
cards.subtitle: I'm Less Biased
cards.description: Recognizing biases in others, not self.
cards.example: Everyone else biased, I see objectively.
cards.tip: You have biases too - this proves it!
